title: Curt Wittlin
text:
Curt Wittlin (13 April 1941 – 23 September 2019) was a <a href="Swiss%20people">Swiss</a> <a href="philology">philologist</a> and an expert of <a href="medieval">medieval</a> <a href="Catalan%20language">Catalan</a> language and <a href="Catalan%20literature">literature</a>.
Biography.
Wittlin studied romance philology in <a href="Basel">Basel</a> with <a href="Germ%C3%A0%20Colon">Germà Colon</a>, and later in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="Florence">Florence</a> and <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>. He got his PhD in 1965 with a thesis about the Catalan translation of <a href="Brunetto%20Latini">Brunetto Latini</a>'s "Treasure" by <a href="Guillem%20de%20Copons">Guillem de Copons</a>. He became Professor of Romance Philology and Historical Linguistics at the <a href="University%20of%20Saskatchewan">University of Saskatchewan</a> in <a href="Saskatoon">Saskatoon</a> (<a href="Canada">Canada</a>), where he arrived in 1967.
He became a specialist in the edition of medieval translations in Europe of texts by <a href="Cicero">Cicero</a>, <a href="Saint%20Augustine">Saint Augustine</a> and <a href="John%20of%20Wales">John of Wales</a>, among others. He also worked on <a href="Ramon%20Llull">Ramon Llull</a> and on the history of medieval Catalan libraries. The Catalan writer to which he devoted most of his life was <a href="Francesc%20Eiximenis">Francesc Eiximenis</a>. Wittlin published most of the modern editions of Francesc Eiximenis' works and wrote many studies and articles about Eiximenis.
In 1997 he became a member of the <a href="Institute%20of%20Catalan%20Studies">Institute of Catalan Studies</a> and from 1990 to 1993 he was president of the <a href="North%20American%20Catalan%20Society">North American Catalan Society</a>. In 2000 he received the "Creu de Sant Jordi" (Saint George cross), a high distinction given by the regional Catalan government.
